channel.title: A topic to ramble
channel.description:
I just thought of this concept, so I'd like to share it. Having a topic to ramble philosophy in is a lot of fun. :)
Anyway. Take this concept: given the amount of people on the earth, at every moment of time (no matter how low the order of magnitude), there is always a single person awake and conscious at any given moment of time. It's almost presumable this case has been ongoing since the advent of humans and human derivatives (such as species prior to homosapien). Does mankinds cumulative consciousness somehow represent our constant struggle against death, and our continual persistence to live?
Perhaps that's unclear. Here's for a terrible analogy: imagine a captain of a small wooden boat, battling it up against a maelstrom or a hurricane or something. He's constantly working the lines, holding the ship steady, throwing anchor if need be, anything to save his own life and his ship. If he lets his grip go for one second, it may be all over for him. I consider this like mankind. Our continual consciousness adds to our overall "battle" against inevitable destruction. It's almost as though our cumulative consciousness somehow blinds use and provides ignorance for the ultimate reality of death and the ending of our own lives, and thereby the lives of our species.
If this remains unclear, that's fine. :P Maybe I'll post more ramblings I come up with. Post any replies or corollaries as you see fit. :)

item.title: A topic to ramble
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

Why would I care about death? I can’t stop it. Embrace it Taharok! Embrace it my friend! Use the force.

Read full topic

item.title: A topic to ramble
item.dc:creator: @Aff Aff
item.description:
@Aff wrote:

Taharok:

I consider this like mankind. Our continual consciousness adds to our overall “battle” against inevitable destruction.

we aren’t the only species that has at least one awake at every moment. your theory would apply to a variety of animals, thus saying that every animal is as destructive as us?

idk if that was your point or not, you kind of mixed diarrhea with pepto bismol and expected us to understand which color would be dominant

Read full topic

item.title: A topic to ramble
item.dc:creator: @Owner_Zack_of_Pwnage Owner Zack of PwnageScape
item.description:
@Owner_Zack_of_Pwnage wrote:

Well, your arguing one sidedly Taharok. There has to be someone awake at all times, because of all the different time zones, locations, etc. But, I see your point. I’ve just thought about that now.

Read full topic

item.title: A topic to ramble
item.dc:creator: @Mack_n_cheese Mack n cheese
item.description:
@Mack_n_cheese wrote:

to me, basically what you said, was if we sleep, or everyone in the world sleeps, we’re gonna die.

my mind starts running when i try to go to bed, so i’ll probably end up posting something here later.

Read full topic

item.title: A topic to ramble
item.dc:creator: @Chrix Chrix
item.description:
@Chrix wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:9, topic:435743”][quote author=Chrix link=topic=538463.msg3942026#msg3942026 date=1331491864]
The total effect of the culture industry is one of anti-enlightenment, in which, as Horkheimer and I have noted, enlightenment, that is the progressive technical domination of nature, becomes mass deception and is turned into a means for fettering consciousness. It impedes the development of autonomous, independent individuals who judge and decide consciously for themselves. – Theodore Adorno

Resource: http://www.pages.drexel.edu/~philclub/quote_script.html
[/quote]

I would agree that it impedes the ability for maybe self defense and self preservation, but I don’t yet agree with a lack of free choice or free thought. I mean going down that path really connects back to dystopian literature, especially of the 1984 and We varieties.[/quote]

This is my thoughts as well here is another one,

Death does not concern us, because as long as we exist, death is not here. And when it does come, we no longer exist.
Epicurus

Read more: http://www.brainyquote.com/quotes/authors/e/epicurus.html#ixzz1os0cITOZ

Read full topic

It impedes the development of autonomous, independent individuals who judge and decide consciously for themselves. – Theodore Adorno

item.description:
@Daginith wrote:

[size=large]What[/size]
Were you smoking?

item.title: A topic to ramble
item.dc:creator: @vManlyMan vManlyMan
item.description:
@vManlyMan wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:4, topic:435743”][quote author=vManlyMan link=topic=538463.msg3941188#msg3941188 date=1331425978]
I think a better explanation to why someone is always awake is the way the earth is positioned in the universe. The sun is always facing one section of the planet, and it’s hard to sleep with the sun in your eyes.

[/quote]

Clearly you missed the point of this topic. :P[/quote]

I didn’t miss the point, I just don’t agree with it. And rather than get into an argument about humans fighting death, I’d rather post my version of a troll.

Read full topic

item.title: A topic to ramble
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“vManlyMan, post:3, topic:435743”]I think a better explanation to why someone is always awake is the way the earth is positioned in the universe. The sun is always facing one section of the planet, and it’s hard to sleep with the sun in your eyes.

Clearly you missed the point of this topic.

[quote=“Rodgerwilco, post:2, topic:435743”]Sounds like some people are paranoid. :S

Our continual consciousness adds to our overall “battle” against inevitable destruction.[/quote]

Not in the slightest. This topic was merely a proposition; an occurring thought. I really assumed the reader would lead to the conclusion that, if one can realize that mankind as a whole is always conscious, what would happen in a scenario of unconsciousness. Ie, what would happen in the world when all humans are unconscious? Does life really go on?

I believe there was a show that failed on NBC a few years back that played on this theory. I can’t recall the name, but I recall everyone in the world blacking out for an exact amount of time, and seeing something in the future. Pretty cool idea, and partially related.

Also, this idea plays well into superconsciousness and zen buddhism.

Read full topic
